is only valid around Egyptian fraction.
in continued or Egyptian fraction is only valid once and before any commas.
in continued or Egyptian fraction is only valid after \";\".
in mixed number is only valid once and before \"/\".
in fraction is only valid once.

The Qonvert logo is a dashing version of ‚Ñö, the symbol for the set of rational numbers.

Convert rational numbers between different bases and different representations:
 https://github.com/Anypodetos/qonvert

    h2 {background: rgb(32, 32, 32)}

    .roman-frame {border-color: white}
</style>
<style> a {color: rgb(0, 157, 224)} /* azure_light */ code {border-bottom-color: rgb(0, 118, 168)} /* azure_dark */ </style>

Overview

This app lets you convert numbers from the set ‚Ñö of rational numbers between different bases (including nonstandard numeral systems), and between different representations such as positional notation and fractions (including improper, mixed and continued ones). The numbers can have basically arbitrary size and precision.

To copy a result to the input line, short-tap it, and to copy it to the clipboard, long-tap it.

Choosing input and output systems

Choose an input base from 2 to 36 via the slider or the shortcut buttons in the lower part of the screen, and an output base via the corresponding controls in the upper part.

The coloured buttons on the right let you switch between various kinds of numeral systems (standard, balanced, bijective, and Roman), on which more below. Not every option can be combined with every base; for invalid combinations, the buttons are greyed and the app uses the standard positional number system.

Standard positional notation

If you choose to convert from standard DECimal (base 10) to standard HEXadecimal (base 16), an input of (say) 345 is interpreted as 3√ó102+4√ó101+5√ó100 and converted to 1√ó162+5√ó161+9√ó160, which is displayed as 159.

Digits from 0 to 9 work as expected. Those with values higher than 9 are represented by letters, from A = 10 to Z = 35; and they are case insensitive so you don‚Äôt have to use Shift for your input. Spaces are ignored.

Non-integers

Digits after a radix point . are of course interpreted as the fractional part of the number: 1.A6 in DOZenal (base 12) is 1√ó120+10√ó12‚àí1+6√ó12‚àí2 = 1.875. If there is a repeating part, mark its start with a single quote \': For example, 0.1\'486 means 0.1486486486‚Ä¶, and 21\'3.4 means 213.43434‚Ä¶.

The result of your conversion has always either a finite number of digits after the radix point or a repeating part. Sometimes, though, the representation can be very long. To keep the app from freezing, the search for an exact representation stops after 300 digits by default. You can change this value in the settings.

If your screen is too small to show all the output formats (positional, fraction, mixed number, continued fraction), you can swipe the output area up and down.

Fractions

Type a numerator and a denominator separated with a slash /, as in 6/8 or 1.5/2. Fractions are reduced or expanded as necessary, so both of these inputs will result in 3/4.

For mixed numbers, separate integer and fractional part with an underscore _: for example, 1_9/8 or 1.\'3 _ 1/3. Fractions with an absolute value over 1 will be shown both as improper fractions (17/8 or 5/3 in our examples) and as mixed numbers (2_1/8 or 1_2/3).

Continued fractions

Continued fractions start with an integer part, followed by a semicolon ; and a comma-separated list of denominators. Square brackets are used for output but are optional for input.

2;3,4, for example, means 2 + 1/(3 + 1/4), which evaluates to 2.\'307692, 30/13, and 2_4/13.

Input of non-integer numbers, including fractions, is okay: 1.5; 2/3, 1_1/5 is simplified to [2; 6]. All continued fractions are displayed with positive denominators, so -3;-1,-1,-18 becomes [‚àí4; 2, 18].

Egyptian fractions (input only)

Egyptian fractions are sums of unit fractions. Input works as with continued fractions, only with curly braces: {2;3,4} is interpreted as 2 + 1/3 + 1/4, evaluating to 2.58\'3, 31/12, 2_7/12, and [2; 1, 1, 2, 2].

Negative numbers

You can type negative numbers either in ordinary notation with a leading minus -, or in complement notation with two leading points ..: these points basically mean ‚Äúthe highest digit in this base repeated all the way to the left‚Äù. Complement notation is known from computing, where ‚àí1 is represented as hexadecimal FFFFFFFF, ‚àí2 as FFFFFFFE, and so on (with as many F‚Äôs as there is space). So, typing ..D in hexadecimal or ..7 in decimal both mean ‚àí3.

Output of negative numbers is either in ordinary or complement notation, depending on the switch at the top right.

Input with base tokens

You can type in numbers in standard binary, octal, decimal, dozenal and hexadecimal without changing the input base, and even use different bases for integer part, numerator and denominator of a fraction, or for the numbers in a continued fraction. To do this, prefix a number with one of these tokens:

  • binary: @
  • octal: %23
  • decimal: $, ‚Ç¨, ¬£, or ¬•
  • dozenal: %
  • hexadecimal: &

Try typing @10010 / &13 or %2312; @1010, $10.

Non-standard numeral systems

Balanced

In balanced numeral systems (the best-known being balanced ternary, i.e. base 3), the letters J to Z have negative values, with Z = ‚àí1, Y = ‚àí2, down to J = ‚àí17. They only work with odd bases. Thus, in balanced ternary, 10Z means 1√ó32+0√ó31‚àí1√ó30 = 8. Negative numbers don‚Äôt need a minus sign in this notation: Z01 means ‚àí1√ó32+0√ó31+1√ó30 = ‚àí8

Complement notation is disabled for balanced numeral systems.

Bijective

In bijective systems of a base b, the digits go from 1 to b instead of 0 to b‚àí1. There are two variants: ‚Äúbijective 1‚Äù uses the digits 1 to 9 and A to Z as in standard notation; ‚Äúbijective A‚Äù uses A = 1, B = 2, ‚Ä¶ Z = 26 and only works up to hexavigesimal (base 26). So, the first natural numbers in decimal bijective 1 are 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, A (=10), 11, 12, ‚Ä¶, 19, 1A, 21, ‚Ä¶, and the first natural numbers in hexavigesimal bijective A are A, B, C, D, ‚Ä¶, X, Y, Z, AA, AB, AC, ‚Ä¶. Zero is technically an empty string; it is denoted with Œª.

Numbers with a radix point don‚Äôt work well with bijective systems, so non-integers are only displayed as fractions.

Roman numerals

Roman numerals are always base 10. They can contain the letters I V X L C D M. Symbols for larger values are composed like so: I)) = ‚ÜÅ = 5000, ((I)) = ‚ÜÇ = 10 000, I))) = ‚Üá = 50 000, and (((I))) = ‚Üà = 100 000.

One traditional way for expressing still larger numbers is to enclose them in a frame to multiply with 100 000, or in nested frames for even higher powers. Qonvert uses pipes | for this purpose: |VI|((I))MM = VI‚ÜÇMM = 6 12000. You can omit the leading pipes, and replace pipes with exclamation marks for better accessibility: ||V|M|II = V!M!II = 5 01000 00002. (The Romans certainly wouldn‚Äôt have understood the notation with repeated frames, but there doesn‚Äôt seem to be any valid way of expressing huge numbers in Roman.)

The integer part may be followed by S (semis) for a half and one or more dots (use for example .‚Äôs and :‚Äôs) for a twelfth each. N for nulla or nihil means zero.

When Roman input is set, Arabic (i.e. standard decimal) input is also accepted so you need less switching between input systems.

Additionally, when an output system other than Roman is selected, positive integers are also displayed as Roman numerals in the second output line.

Unicode characters

Inputs that are integers between hexadecimal 20 and 31 FFF (decimal 32 and 204 799) are not only converted to their representation in the output base (and to Roman numerals), but also to the corresponding Unicode character.

Conversely, type double quotes \" followed by any character to find its Unicode encoding. This only works for single characters, not composed ones such as certain letter-diacritic combinations, people with skin tones, or flags.

The Web has excellent sources to find Unicode characters by name; but if you want to know the Unicode representation of the tortoise in balanced undecimal, Qonvert is your only source. (The answer is 1YX215.)

And if anybody asks ‚Äúwhy‚Äù, the answer is ‚Äúbecause‚Äù.

Gestures

  • Output area: short-tap copies to input line, long-tap copies to clipboard.
  • Base buttons: left/right swipe decreases/increases base by 1.
  • ‚Äúin: base‚Äù and ‚Äúout: base‚Äù: tap displays digit range for currently selected base and number system.
  • Number system buttons: long-tap toggles between standard and balanced.
  • Clear button: long-tap sets input and output to standard decimal.
  • History: tap copies to input line.

Input syntax

Base tokens

  • @: standard binary
  • %23: standard octal
  • $, ‚Ç¨, ¬£, ¬•: standard decimal
  • %: standard dozenal
  • &: standard hexadecimal

Digits

  • 0..9
  • A..Z: normally 10..35, in bijective A: 1..26
  • J..Z in balanced: ‚àí17..‚àí1

Negative numbers

  • -: minus sign
  • ..: complement notation

Non-integers

  • .: radix point
  • \': start of repeating part
  • /: fraction slash
  • _: separates integer and fraction in a mixed number (e.g. 2_1/8)
  • [ ; , , ]: continued fraction (the brackets are optional)
  • { ; , , }: Egyptian fraction

Roman numerals

  • I V X L C D M: 1..1000
  • I)) ((I)) I))) (((I))): 5000, 10 000, 50 000, 100 000
  • | or !: multiplies by 100 000
  • . : S: uncia = twelfth, sextans = sixth, semis = half
  • N: nulla/nihil = zero

Unicode characters

  • \"üíÉ: Dancer

Version 1.1.0

The switches for balanced numeral systems have been replaced with dropdown menus which let you choose between standard, balanced, bijective and Roman numerals. You can still toggle between standard and balanced systems with a long tap. See the Help page for how these new systems work.

On the Preferences screen, you can activate new base buttons for hexavigesimal (base 26).

Input of Egyptian fractions is supported: {2;3,4} is interpreted as 2 + 1/3 + 1/4 = 2_7/12.

You can now use fraction characters such as ¬Ω and use them in numbers: 2¬æ.

The main menu has a new entry ‚ÄúCheat sheet‚Äù with an overview over the control gestures on the main screen, as well as the input syntax. (Now you can swipe right to get there.)

Many fixes and improvements ‚Äì for example, calculating digits of long repeating parts is faster now.

Version 1.0.0

Initial release with standard and balanced numeral systems as well as Roman output for integers and Unicode characters.

Thank you for using Qonvert!

This is a toy and maybe an educational tool, and it‚Äôs free. It was written by me, Anypodetos, because I couldn‚Äôt find an app that could do that kind of stuff.

If you have any suggestions or questions, or you want to report a bug, or you just want to tell me whether you like this app, please contact me.
